Aliphatic C–H hydroxylation activity and durability of a nickel complex catalyst according to the molecular structure of the bis(oxazoline) ligands Takashi Izumi Conceptualization Validation Investigation Writing – original draft Naki Matsuba Validation Investigation Jun Nakazawa Methodology Investigation Data curation Shiro Hikichi Conceptualization Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition ⁎ Department of Material and Life Chemistry, Faculty of Engineering, Kanagawa University, 3-27-1 Rokkakubashi, Kanagawa-ku, Yokohama 221-8686, Japan Department of Material and Life Chemistry, Faculty of Engineering Kanagawa University 3-27-1 Rokkakubashi Yokohama Kanagawa-ku 221-8686 Japan Department of Material and Life Chemistry, Faculty of Engineering, Kanagawa University, 3-27-1 Rokkakubashi, Kanagawa-ku, Yokohama 221-8686, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Applicability of the oxazoline-based compounds, bis(2-oxazolynyl)methane (BOX) and 2,6-bis(2-oxazolynyl)pyridine (PyBOX), as supporting ligands of nickel(II) complexes for the catalysis of aliphatic CH hydroxylation with m-CPBA (meta-chloroperoxybenzoic acid) was explored. Substituent groups at the fourth and fifth positions of oxazoline rings and the bridgehead carbon atom of the BOX derivatives affected the catalytic performances toward cyclohexane hydroxylation. Presence of dioxygen led to a reduced catalytic performance of the nickel complexes, except in the case of a fully substituted BOX ligand complex. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Bis(oxazoline) ligands Alkane hydroxylation Meta-chloroperoxybenzoic acid Nickel complex catalysts Ligand effect 1 Introduction Direct oxygenation of organic compounds, especially hydroxylation of a non-activated aliphatic C–H group, is an important organic reaction for the construction of various functional compounds [1]. In biological system, O2 is utilized as oxidant for CH hydroxylation catalyzed by iron- and copper-containing oxygenases such as cytochrome P-450 and methane monooxygenase, although a sacrificial reductant (e.g. NADPH) is required [2,a,b,c]. For laboratory-scale oxygenation reactions, organic peroxides are convenient oxygen sources. Due to a relatively low OO bond dissociation energy (BDE) [3,a,b], activation of peroxides gives reactive radical species which can abstract hydrogen atoms from aliphatic C–H bonds; the coupling of the resulting alkyl radicals with oxygen species then affords oxygenated compounds [4]. However, diffusion of the highly reactive radical species reduces the yield of the desired oxygenated compound. To achieve high chemo- and regioselective reactions, appropriate catalysts should be designed to activate organic peroxides under mild conditions [5,a,b,c]. So far, several nickel(II) complexes with tri-, tetra- and pentadentate chelating ligands have been shown to be efficient alkane hydroxylation catalysts, activating meta-chloroperoxybenzoic acid (m-CPBA) oxidant [6–17]. Combination of a bidentate ligand and another chelating ligand also gave catalytically active nickel complexes [18]. In addition, some nickel complexes with a single bidentate ligand have been reported as alkane oxidizing catalysts [19, 20]. Bis(2-oxazolynyl)methane derivatives, namely BOX ligands, are used as a supporting ligand of the metal center for various catalysts of organic reactions [21,a,b]. From the perspective of designing the catalysts, the structural controllability of BOX is attractive. Various substituent groups can be introduced onto the oxazoline rings at both the fourth and fifth positions. Also, the bridgehead methylene unit connecting the two oxazoline rings is modifiable; the hydrogen atoms can be substituted to alkyl or other functional groups. In addition, 2,6-bis(2-oxazolynyl)pyridine, namely PyBOX, can be regarded as a BOX derivative in which the bridgehead part is a pyridine instead of a methylene unit. To date, various BOX ligands have been developed, and some of them are available commercially. In this work, we have explored applicability, scope and limitations of several BOX derivatives to a nickel(II) complex catalyst for alkane hydroxylation with m-CPBA. Five commercially available BOX derivatives L1–L5 were evaluated (Fig. 1 ). The reported Ni/m-CPBA catalytic systems were inert toward aromatic C–H oxidation. Therefore, we selected a phenyl group as the substituent to introduce onto the oxazoline rings (except L4). As a control, an isopropyl group was also examined as a substituent group (L4). For the phenyl-substituted oxazoline donors, only the fourth position was substituted in L1 and L5 and both the fourth and fifth positions were substituted in L2 and L3. For the bridgehead part, dimethyl-substituted derivatives (L1, L2 and L4) and a non-substituted methylene compound (L3) were compared. A phenyl-substituted PyBOX L5 was also tested as the bridgehead pyridyl group would function as an additional nitrogen donor, and the structural properties of the resulting nickel center supported by L5 with meridional tridentate fashion might be different from those of other nickel centers supported by the bidentate ligands L1–L4. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and physicochemical characterization techniques All manipulations (except the catalytic tests under air) were performed under argon by standard Schlenk techniques. CH2Cl2, Et2O and MeCN were purified over a Glass Contour Solvent Dispending System under Ar atmosphere. Purchased ligands, 2,2-bis(4R-phenyl-2-oxazolinyl)propane (L1: TCI, Tokyo, Japan), 2,2-bis[(4R, 5S)-diphenyl-2-oxazolinyl]propane (L2: Aldrich, St. Louis, MO, USA), bis[(4R, 5S)-diphenyl-2-oxazolinyl]methane (L3: Aldrich), 2,2-bis(4S- isopropyl-2-oxazolinyl)propane (L4: Aldrich), and 2,6-bis(4R- phenyl-2-oxazolinyl)pyridine (L5: TCI), were used as received. m-CPBA (Kanto Chemical, Tokyo, Japan) was washed with KH2PO4 NaOH buffer solution (pH 7.4) and pure water to remove meta-chlorobenzoic acid. Other reagents of the highest grade commercially available were used without further purification. UV/Vis spectra were recorded on a V650 (JASCO, Tokyo, Japan). Mass spectra were measured on a JMS-T100LC (JEOL, Tokyo, Japan) using an electrospray ionization (ESI) method. Gas chromatographic (GC) analyses were carried out on GC-2010 and GC-2025 instruments (Shimadzu, Kyoto, Japan) with a flame ionization detector equipped with Rtx-5 (on GC-2010) and Rtx-WAX (on GC-2025) capillary column (length = 30 m, i.d. = 0.25 mm, thickness = 0.25 μm, Restek, Bellefonte, PA, USA). GC–MS analyses were conducted on a PARVUM2 system (Shimadzu, Kyoto, Japan) equipped with a CP-Chirasil-Dex CB capillary column (length = 25 m, i.d. = 0.25 mm, thickness = 0.36 μm, Agilent, Santa Clara, CA, USA). Single crystal X-ray diffraction data was collected using a Saturn 70 CCD area detector system with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (Rigaku, Tokyo, Japan). Crystal information files (CIF) of the complex reported in this paper has been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data center as supplementary publication CCDC 2,025,859. This data can be obtained online free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data center at www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data request/cif. 2.2 Confirmation of nickel complex formation 2.2.1 ESI-MS and UV–vis analysis of the complexes A mixture of 1.0 mL of a 2.0 mM MeOH solution of Ni(OAc)2•4H2O and 1.0 mL of 2.0 mM MeCN solution of the ligand was stirred for 1 h in a Schlenk tube at ambient temperature under Ar. The resulting reaction mixture was analyzed by ESI-MS. In addition, crude nickel complexes were analyzed by ESI-MS and UV–vis spectroscopy. After stirring for 1 h, the volatiles were evaporated. The crude nickel complex with the corresponding ligand was obtained by extraction with CH2Cl2 and washing with n-hexane. 2.2.2 Isolation of [Ni(L3-H)2] An MeCN solution (20 mL) of L3 (184 mg; 0.402 mmol) was added to a methanol solution (20 mL) of Ni(OAc)2•4H2O (50 mg; 0.201 mmol) at RT and the solution was stirred for 1 h. After the removal of volatiles by evaporation, the resulting crude reddish-brown powder was suspended in CH2Cl2 and the insoluble compounds were removed by filtration through a celite pad. CH2Cl2 was evaporated from the filtrate and the resulting powder was washed with Et2O to yield a reddish-brown powder of [Ni(L3-H)2]. The powder was collected by filtration and recrystallized from slow diffusion of CH2Cl2/n-hexane to afford a reddish-brown crystal suitable for X-ray crystallographic analysis. 2.3 Catalytic alkane oxidation with m-CPBA In situ-generated catalysts were prepared as follows. A mixture of 1.0 mL of 2.0 mM MeOH solution of Ni(OAc)2•4H2O and 1.0 mL of 2.0 mM MeCN solution of the ligand was stirred for 1 h in a Schlenk tube at ambient temperature under Ar. Evaporation of the volatiles yielded a powder of nickel complexes with L1–L5. The catalytic reactions were carried out in the same Schlenk tube. The [Ni(L3-H)2] (2.0 μmol), which was prepared as described above, was also applied to the catalytic test. The organic products of the catalytic reactions were analyzed quantitatively by GC or GC–MS with an internal standard. The yields of products indicated in Tables 1 – 4 were average values obtained by three times experiments. 2.3.1 Oxidation of cyclohexane To a Schlenk tube containing the catalyst, cyclohexane (15.0 mmol), nitrobenzene (0.10 mmol; as internal standard for quantitative analysis on GC) and a mixture of MeCN (1 mL) and CH2Cl2 (1 mL) was added. After dissolving the catalyst, a CH2Cl2 (2 mL) solution of m-CPBA (2.0 mmol) was added and stirred at 308 K under Ar or air. To monitor product formation, 0.1 mL of the reaction mixture was collected at certain times and quenched with a dichloromethane solution (0.5 mL) of triphenylphosphine (10 mg), then the solution was subjected to GC analysis (GC-2010 equipped with Rtx-5 capillary column). 2.3.2 Oxidation of methylcyclohexane To a Schlenk tube containing the catalyst, methylcyclohexane (13.0 mmol), nitrobenzene (0.10 mmol; as internal standard for quantitative analysis on GC) and a CH2Cl2 (1 mL) solution of m-CPBA (0.20 mmol) was added and stirred at RT under Ar. A GC-2025 equipped with Rtx-WAX capillary column was used for analysis of the products. 2.3.3 Oxidation of ethylbenzene The reaction conditions were essentially the same as those used for the cyclohexane oxidation under Ar. Products were analyzed by GC–MS. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Confirmation of the formation of the nickel complexes We planned to evaluate the catalytic performance of the in situ-generated complex formed via reaction of nickel(II) acetate with a same stoichiometric amount of the ligand. Prior to catalytic reaction tests, we confirmed formation of the corresponding nickel complexes with L1–L5. ESI-MS of 1:1 mixtures of Ni(OAc)2∙4H2O (MeOH solution) and the ligand (MeCN solution) showed the ion peaks attributed to the nickel complexes with the corresponding BOX derivatives (Fig. S1). For the L3 mixture, a characteristic molecular ion peak assignable as [Ni(L3)2 – H]+ was observed. Notably, conversion of BOX to a β-diketiminate type bisoxazolinate ligand via deprotonation from the bridgehead methylene moiety has been reported [22–24]. As expected, conversion of the methylene-containing L3 to the corresponding bisoxazolinate ligand was confirmed by X-ray crystallographic analysis of the isolated complex (Fig. 2 ). No counter anion exists in the crystal lattice, and that indicates the formula of this complex is [Ni(L3-H)2] where L3-H denotes the anionic bisoxazolinate ligand. Bond angles of CCC with the bridgehead carbon atom are close to 120° (120.4(2) and 120.8(2)°). Bond lengths of CC from the bridgehead carbon to 2-oxazolinyl carbons (1.369(3), 1.381(3), 1.388(3) and 1.390(3) Å) are somewhat shorter than the typical CC single bond length. These structural properties provide evidence that the bridgehead carbon atoms have sp 2 hybridization. In addition, elongation of the N=C bond lengths (1.312(3), 1.315(3), 1.327(3) and 1.329(3) Å) compared to those of the metal ligands (c.a. 1.29 Å) and non-metalated 2-oxazoline derivatives (c.a. 1.27 Å), as well as the similarity of the bond lengths of Cbridgehead-C2-oxazolinyl, indicates delocalization of an electron onto the NCCCN framework of the bisoxazolinate. Arrangement of the phenyl groups as (4R, 5S) is retained during the complex formation. Interconversion between the bisoxazolinate and BOX was reversible by protonation and deprotonation at the bridgehead carbon atom [24]. A CH2Cl2 solution of the homoleptic bisoxazolinate ligand complex [Ni(L3-H)2] showed characteristic absorption bands around 485 nm and 610 nm in the UV–vis spectrum. Intensities of these bands were decreased on addition of acetic acid, and recovering of these absorption bands occurred on the addition of triethylamine (Fig. 3 ). Therefore, reaction of nickel(II) acetate and L3 in the presence of protic compound would yield an equilibrium mixture of [Ni(L3-H)2] and non-deprotonated L3 complexes such as [Ni(OAc)2(L3)]. Existence of this species was suggested by the detection of ion peaks attributed to [Ni(OAc)(L3)]+ in the ESI-MS spectra of the reaction mixture of Ni(OAc)2•4H2O and L3 (Fig. S1(c)). UV–vis spectra of other ligand complexes were also evaluated (Fig. S2). Spectral patterns of the nickel(II) complexes with the methylated-bridgehead containing ligands, L1, L2 and L4, were similar to each other, but clearly different from that of the above-mentioned [Ni(L3-H)2]. The meridional tridentate ligand L5 complex showed a different spectral pattern due to coordination of the bridgehead pyridyl donor. 3.2 Catalytic reactions 3.2.1 Cyclohexane oxidation Catalytic performances of the in situ-generated nickel complexes with L1–L5 and the isolated [Ni(L3-H)2] toward cyclohexane oxidation with m-CPBA were examined (Table 1 ). Under an argon atmosphere, all in situ-generated complexes exhibited enough activity with moderate alcohol selectivity (A/(K + Lac) values were around 5–6), although reaction rates and total turnover numbers (TONs) were lower than those of the previously reported nickel(II) complexes with tris(pyridylmethyl)amine (TPA) and its oxazoline analogues [6, 7, 17]. In the absence of the BOX ligands (i.e. genuine Ni(OAc)2•4H2O was applied as a catalyst), the yields of products were comparable with those of the control experiments [25]. Formation of chlorobenzene ( Ph-Cl ) indicated homolytic OO cleavage of m-CPBA proceeded during the catalytic process. The order of the alcohol yield and TON were L1 > L3 > L2, which seems to reflect the structural nature controlled by the distal substituent groups. Both the phenyl groups introduced on the fifth positions of the oxazolines (L2 and L3) and the methyl groups attached on the bridgehead carbon (L1 and L2) are away from the nickel center in the complex. The isolated bisoxazolinate complex [Ni(L3-H)2] showed a similar activity to that of the in situ-generated L3 complex. In the examined catalytic reaction conditions, a large excess of m-CPBA existed which also functioned as a proton source, reacting with the bridgehead in L3–H. Catalytic activities of the complexes, except the L2 derivative, were decreased under air. In particular, the homoleptic bisoxazolinate complex [Ni(L3–H)2], and the in situ-generated complexes with the 4-isopropyl substituted ligand L4 and PyBOX L5 showed remarkable reductions in activity and alcohol selectivity. Moderate reduction of the TON and alcohol selectivity also occurred with the in situ-generated complexes with L1 and L3. Using L1, we estimated the effect of the atmosphere toward catalytic performance as summarized in Table 2 . Under an O2 atmosphere, TON and A/(K + Lac) values were further decreased compared to those under air. Addition of water under Ar exhibited a slight inhibition of catalysis. Therefore, O2 in air inhibited the present oxidation catalysis. A reason for the lower alcohol selectivity under air for all complexes might be due to autoxidation via reaction of the radical species with dioxygen. A cyclohexyl radical was trapped by O2 to give a cyclohexylperoxyl radical and the following bimolecular reaction namely Russel-termination yielded the 1: 1 mixture of cyclohexanol and cyclohexanone (see Process (C) in Fig. 4 ) [26]. Stability of the reaction intermediates toward dioxygen would be critical to the catalytic activity depending on the ligands. The characteristics of each ligand would also influence the lifetime of the generated catalysts. Aerobic oxidation of the C–H group at the bridgehead part of BOX has been reported [27], and therefore, deactivation of [Ni(L3–H)2] could be due to the oxidation of the bridgehead moiety of the ligand. According to the proposed reaction mechanism in the previous literatures, an air-sensitive nickel(I) species may be formed after substrate hydroxylation, as shown in the process of “catalytic hydroxylation with m-CPBA” as Process (A) in Fig. 4 [7]. We had reported that the formation of a nickel(II)-chloride complex through the spontaneous decomposition of a nickel(II)-acylperoxo complex in CH2Cl2 under Ar suggested the existence of a nickel(I) intermediate which abstracted chlorine atom from CH2Cl2 [10]. Gade and coworkers reported that dioxygen activation on a nickel(I) center supported by an amide donor-containing pincer-type tridentate bisoxazoline ligand resulted in the oxygenation of a methine C–H of an isopropyl group attached to the fourth position of an oxazoline [28]. For the 4-phenyl oxazoline-based analogous pincer ligand complex, the C–H at the fourth position of the oxazoline was also oxidized [29]. Therefore, oxygenation of the isopropyl group on L4 and the fourth position of the oxazoline on L5 might proceed through O2 activation on the nickel(I) center, although molecular structures of the precursor complexes and putative ligand-oxygenated complexes had not been characterized. TON of the L2 complex under air was higher than that under Ar, although the alcohol selectivity was decreased moderately under air due to additional autoxidation. In other words, the L2 complex resisted oxidative degradation. Very recently, Qin and Hartwig reported nickel complexes-mediated alkanes oxidation with m-CPBA under air at 50 °C [20]. They proposed the nickel complexes catalyzed the decomposition of m-CPBA to generate an acyloxyl radical and the hydroxylation of cyclohexane proceeded through radical chain reaction as Process (B) in Fig. 4. The lack of an effect of ligands was the basis for this proposal. In our reaction system, chlorobenzene was formed (see Table 1) and that indicated the involvement of the acyloxyl radical. In addition, cyclohexyl radical was also involved as was evidenced by the formation of chlorocyclohexane (i.e., “Chlorination” as Process (D) in Fig. 4). Therefore, the radical chain reaction might be involved, too. However, the significant effect of the ligands was observed in our system. Especially, regioselectivity on the oxidation of methylcyclohexane (see next section) suggests the contribution of a nickel-based oxidant. Such difference on the ligand effect indicated that reaction mechanism of the nickel complexes-catalyzed alkane hydroxylation with m-CPBA is varied depending on the structural and electronic properties of the ligands as well as the reaction conditions. 3.2.2 Methylcyclohexane oxidation In order to confirm the reactivity of the metal-based oxidant, methylcyclohexane was used as the probe substrate (Table 3 ). To clarify the ligand effect and to maintain the homogeneous liquid phase, the ratio of the nickel catalyst to m-CPBA was decreased to 1: 100. Methylcyclohexane contains primary, secondary, and tertiary C–H groups. The tertiary C–H bonds of the substrates are sterically crowded, although their bond dissociation energy (BDE) is the lowest. In fact, tertiary C–H oxidation occurred mainly via thermal activation of m-CPBA without the catalyst by radical chain reaction. For the oxidation mediated by the metal-based oxidant with the bulky ligand, the less hindered secondary C–H groups were oxidized preferentially [10, 17]. For the oxidation of methylcyclohexane with m-CPBA by all complexes, the total amount of the secondary C–H oxidized products was greater than the tertiary C–H oxidized alcohol. In addition, low 3°/2° values (selectivity of the tertiary alcohols normalized by the number of hydrogen atoms attached on the carbon) of the catalysts bearing L1–L5 showed that the alkane hydroxylation was mediated by the strong oxidant formed on the nickel complexes [17]. The order of total TON was L4 ~ L1 > L5 ~ L2 ~ L3 > L3–H. A lower concentration of m-CPBA compared to that on the reaction of cyclohexane resulted in stabilizing the inactive [Ni(L3–H)2]. Higher activity of the L1 and L4 catalysts suggested that no phenyl substituents at the fifth position of oxazoline are favorable. Such distal fifth substituents might affect to the arrangement of adjacent fourth substituents, and that would lead to change the accessibility of the substrates to the active sites. Further studies on the coordination structure of the BOX ligands are needed to clarify. 3.2.3 Ethylbenzene oxidation We also examined ethylbenzene oxidation catalysis of the nickel complexes with L1, L3 and L5 (Table 4 ). Major products were racemic 1-phenylethanols. None of the catalysts exhibited enantioselectivity. As described above, preferential hydroxylation of the secondary C–H of methylcyclohexane suggested that a metal-bound strong radical-characteristic oxidant, such as a nickel-oxyl or -oxo species might contribute in the present reaction [17, 30–32]. This active oxidant would abstract the hydrogen atom from the aliphatic C–H group, and the subsequent reaction of •OH with the formed carbon radical center would yield the alcohol product [20, 26]. The formation of chlorocyclohexane during the oxidation of cyclohexane indicated that a portion of the alkyl radical departed from the coordination sphere of the nickel center as the interaction between the chiral ligand and the formed alkyl radical intermediate was quite weak. Moreover, the rate of the reaction of alkyl radical and Ni-OH species, namely OH-rebound” would be low. In other research, asymmetric allylic C–H oxidation (oxidative esterification) with alkylperoxycarboxylate has been mediated by copper complexes supported by chiral BOX ligands. Notably, a copper(III)-benzoate-alkyl species formed via oxidative addition of an allyl radical to the BOX-supported copper center was proposed as the final intermediate affording the product [33]. In contrast, oxidative addition of the alkyl radical species to the nickel center did not occur in the present nickel-BOX complexes system. 4 Conclusions Commercially available BOX derivatives were applicable to nickel complex catalysts for alkane hydroxylation with m-CPBA. Structural differences depending on the positions of the substituent groups influenced the catalytic performance. The present alkane hydroxylation catalysis of the nickel complexes was inhibited by O2, except the fully substituted ligand (= L2) complex. This was probably due to oxidation of the bridgehead methylene unit (L3), the tertiary C–H groups of the isopropyl group (L4), and the fourth position of the phenyl-substituted oxazoline ring (L5). The higher selectivity of the oxidation of the secondary C–H bonds of methylcyclohexane indicated that the present BOX ligands complexes activated m-CPBA to give a nickel-bound strong oxidant. The radical characteristics of the nickel-bound oxidant provided alkyl radical intermediates. On the ethylbenzene oxidation, none of the examined catalysts exhibited enantioselectivity. To achieve enantioselective hydroxylation, construction of substrate holding pocket surrounding the metal center as like the active sites of enzymes will be required. In this study, we have focused on the correlation between the structure of ligands with a common BOX framework and their catalytic activity. A family of BOX ligands are extensively utilized as metal-supported ligands in catalysts for various organic synthesis. The presented results indicate the scope and limitations of some BOX ligands for application to oxidation reactions. Moreover, we found the catalytic oxidation with m-CPBA was inhibited by molecular oxygen. That is a point has not been paid much attention to. Further exploring on the catalytic mechanism of the related metal complexes with various oxidants will provide useful insights into developing high-performance catalytic reaction systems. coredata.dc:description: Applicability of the oxazoline-based compounds, bis(2-oxazolynyl)methane (BOX) and 2,6-bis(2-oxazolynyl)pyridine (PyBOX), as supporting ligands of nickel(II) complexes for the catalysis of aliphatic CH hydroxylation with m-CPBA (meta-chloroperoxybenzoic acid) was explored. Substituent groups at the fourth and fifth positions of oxazoline rings and the bridgehead carbon atom of the BOX derivatives affected the catalytic performances toward cyclohexane hydroxylation. Presence of dioxygen led to a reduced catalytic performance of the nickel complexes, except in the case of a fully substituted BOX ligand complex.
coredata.dc:title: Aliphatic C–H hydroxylation activity and durability of a nickel complex catalyst according to the molecular structure of the bis(oxazoline) ligands
